author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: Commuter Trains Have Kept Rolling. Will All Those Riders Ever Return?
description: Transit agencies in the New York City region are having to reinvent their railroads to adapt to the shift away from going to the office every day.
content: Before the coronavirus pandemic, New York City’s commuter railroads had one main job: They delivered 300,000 tightly packed passengers to work each morning, and carried them home again in the evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: The U.K. is ending its civilian evacuations from Kabul today.
description: Britain is ending its civilian evacuations from Afghanistan on Saturday, the head of the British armed forces said, telling the BBC that the operation had “gone as well as it could do in the circumstances.”
content: Britain is ending its civilian evacuations from Afghanistan on Saturday, the head of the British armed forces said, telling the BBC that the operation had “gone as well as it could do in the circumstances.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Italy will impose tighter restrictions in Sicily after a surge in cases.
description: A majority of hospitalizations on the southern island have involved the unvaccinated, and many have yet to get shots.
content: The Italian government announced on Friday that it would impose tighter restrictions on the southern island of Sicily, including an outdoor mask mandate. The announcement followed a sharp increase in coronavirus infections and hospitalizations in the region, where vaccination rates are low.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: A Digital Dunkirk: Veterans Online Scramble to Get People Out of Afghanistan
description: Using office software, satellite maps and messaging apps, volunteers are acting like digital guide services to helping American citizens and Afghan allies flee the country.
content: DENVER — Joe Saboe pressed his fingers against his brow in exhaustion and leaned over a laptop as he tried to do what had been drilled into him over and over when he was an Army infantry officer: Leave no one behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Amazon strikes a deal with Affirm, the buy-now pay-later provider.
description: Affirm said it had reached an agreement with the online retail giant to provide its customers with monthly payment plans for purchases of $50 or more.
content: Amazon customers will soon have another payment option at checkout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Rebecca Wasserman-Hone, Who Put Burgundy on the U.S. Map, Dies at 84
description: American born, she fell into the wine business and became a champion of the small vignerons of the Burgundy region and their ancient family farms.
content: Rebecca Wasserman-Hone, the American-born wine exporter who championed the wines and the small artisanal producers of Burgundy, her adopted home, died on Aug. 20 in Beaune, France. She was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Woman Sentenced to 7 Days in Jail for Walking in Yellowstone’s Thermal Area
description: The authorities used her case to warn the public about the dangers of the park’s hot springs, geysers and steam vents.
content: A Connecticut woman was sentenced to seven days in jail for walking on the thermal grounds at Yellowstone National Park, an act the authorities described as extremely dangerous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elliot Ackerman
title: It Shouldn’t Fall to Veterans to Clean Up Biden’s Mess
description: Never have I witnessed a swifter collapse of competence than what I have seen with the U.S. evacuation of Afghanistan.
content: The time was set. At noon Thursday, Marines would swoop in and usher a group of 29 Afghans through Abbey Gate into Kabul Airport for evacuation. With minutes to spare, Ahmad — the leader of the group — was still looking for N., an Afghan man he’d never met. N. had tried, unsuccessfully, to enter through another gate earlier in the day, and he was now hoping to make it in with Ahmad’s group. The Marines would open the gate only once, but luckily they were running behind — potentially giving N. the extra minutes he’d need to find Ahmad in the heaving crowd outside it. I was on the phone with Ahmad. A colleague in another country was texting with N., and we were trying to connect them. Time was running out at the airport gates.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Among the Troops Who Died, Two Women on the Front Line
description: The Defense Department on Saturday officially identified the service members who were killed, and family and friends paid tribute to their lives and their sacrifice.
content: One of the last photos that Marine Sgt. Nicole Gee shared with her family from Afghanistan shows her in dusty body armor with a rifle, her long blond hair pulled back, her hands in tactical gloves. Amid the chaos of Kabul, those hands are carefully cradling a baby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: America’s Founders Lived in a Foreign World
description: What we can, and cannot, learn from our history.
content: As regular readers know, I am a little (OK, more than a little) obsessed with the Early Republic period of American history and spend a lot of my time reading about the Revolution, the Articles of Confederation, the Philadelphia constitutional convention, and the Washington and Adams administrations. One of my takeaways from all of this reading is that for all of our modern-day worship of the founding fathers, we lack of a sense of how foreign their world was as compared to ours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kori Schake
title: What Trump’s Disgraceful Deal With the Taliban Has Wrought
description: The conduct of diplomatic relations shouldn't rest solely on the shoulders of presidents.
content: Believing you’re uniquely capable of bending things to your will is practically a requirement for becoming president of the United States. But too often, in pursuit of such influence over foreign policy, presidents overemphasize the importance of personal diplomacy. Relationships among leaders can build trust — or destroy it — but presidents often overrate their ability to steer both allies and adversaries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Frances Robles
title: When Police Lie, the Innocent Pay. Some Are Fighting Back.
description: Video from body cameras, doorbells and cellphones is revealing discrepancies between what police officers report and what actually happened.
content: The statement from the Rock Hill Police Department was unequivocal about what Travis Price did: He belligerently obstructed officers as they arrested his brother on a gun charge; he shoved them and knocked them with his body; he refused to follow orders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Bryson DeChambeau Soars. Patrick Cantlay Drags Him Back to Earth.
description: After shooting a 60 the previous day, DeChambeau allowed Cantlay to catch up, and the two are tied for the lead at 21 under par heading into the final round at the BMW Championship.
content: OWINGS MILLS, Md. — Bryson DeChambeau stood next to his golf bag on the first tee, contemplating which club to hit on the opening hole of Saturday’s third round at the BMW Championship. When he retrieved an iron rather than his powerful driver, a groan erupted from fans crammed into a grandstand overlooking the tee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor, Eric Schmitt, Zia ur-Rehman, Jim Huylebroek, Najim Rahim and Matthieu Aikins
title: The U.S. retaliates over the airport bombing, days before the withdrawal deadline.
description: The U.S. military said that it had killed its target in the first strike since a deadly attack on the Kabul airport.
content: Two “high-profile” Islamic State militants were killed in a retaliatory airstrike carried out in a mountainous region of Afghanistan following the suicide bombing attack at Kabul’s airport that killed scores of people on Thursday, U.S. military officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Evacuations From Kabul Wind Down as U.S. Prepares to Pull Last Troops
description: Hundreds of thousands of Afghans are still thought to be seeking to flee the country, but President Biden and other global leaders have acknowledged that many will not get out before the deadline.
content: The sweeping international effort to evacuate thousands of vulnerable Afghans and foreign nationals from Kabul’s airport neared completion on Saturday as the United States continued to withdraw its remaining troops from Taliban-controlled Afghanistan after carrying out a retaliatory airstrike in response to a devastating terrorist attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: You Don’t Need to Like Those Vacation Pics
description: In fact, your boss needs some guidance on the downside to oversharing.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How will Ida compare to Katrina?
description: Ida will drive less severe storm surge than Katrina. But it could bring greater winds and rain.
content: Hurricane Ida is expected to make landfall Sunday, threatening to bring dangerous wind, storm surge and rain to the Gulf Coast exactly 16 years after the arrival of Hurricane Katrina, one of the most costly natural disasters in American history, which left more than 1,800 dead and produced more than $100 billion in damages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler and Emily Anthes
title: How the Delta Variant Infiltrated an Elementary School Classroom
description: A detailed study in California found that the variant easily spread from an unvaccinated teacher to children and, in a few cases, their families.
content: An unvaccinated elementary schoolteacher infected with the highly contagious Delta variant spread the virus to half of the students in a classroom, seeding an outbreak that eventually infected 26 people, according to a new report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
title: A reprisal strike killed two ISIS militants and wounded another.
description: Officials refused to give details on the two killed, beyond saying that one was a planner and the other was a facilitator.
content: The Pentagon said that two Islamic State militants were killed and one was wounded in Friday night’s drone strike in Nangarhar Province as part of the American retaliation for the suicide bombing at the Kabul airport that killed scores of people, including 13 American service members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: One Afghan family resettling in the U.S. finds a respite.
description: Zar Mohammad Yousafzai applied for a job with the U.S. military forces in Afghanistan 14 years ago. The money was good, and he believed in the American mission to root out extremists there and develop their homeland.
content: Zar Mohammad Yousafzai applied for a job with the U.S. military forces in Afghanistan 14 years ago. The money was good, and he believed in the American mission to root out extremists there and develop their homeland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: U.S. officials warn Americans again to leave the Kabul airport after Biden says a new attack is ‘highly likely.’
description: Evacuations are slowing as U.S. officials estimate that about 350 Americans are still trying to leave Afghanistan.
content: U.S. officials again warned Americans to leave the Kabul airport area immediately because of a security threat, hours after President Biden said that another terrorist attack there was “highly likely” in the coming days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: ‘Be Patient’
description: Good luck getting over the top of this tough Julian Lim puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I am once again stating that there’s no shame in getting stymied, gobsmacked or blocked by a puzzle, especially on a weekend and especially from a pro constructor. This is Julian Lim’s ninth Saturday puzzle for The Times and it was a major challenge for me. Somehow all my weak spots converged into a sad knowledge gap and I honestly couldn’t even get started on this grid for a couple of passes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: From Kabul Airport to a Houston Walmart: ‘Desperate to Get to America’
description: Members of an Afghan family endured kidnappings, threats and car bombs over the decade they waited for U.S. visas. Now they’re starting a new life in Texas.
content: HOUSTON — As an interpreter working alongside the U.S. military in Afghanistan, Zar Mohammad Yousafzai taught English to Afghan soldiers and Pashto to American troops. He helped negotiate agreements with tribal leaders to halt attacks on Americans and instructed Afghans on how to use American weapons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Myanmar’s Monks, Leaders of Past Protests, Are Divided Over the Coup
description: Some senior members of the Buddhist clergy have given their blessing to the generals in power. But hundreds of lower-ranking monks have been jailed for protesting.
content: Day after day, despite a raging pandemic and the threat of snipers’ bullets, a small band of Buddhist monks in burgundy robes gathers in the city of Mandalay in Myanmar. Their acts of dissent last only a few minutes, hasty candlelight vigils or flash-mob protests in the shadow of a monastery with gilded eaves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathy Ryan and Maureen Dowd
title: A Newsroom, on Pause
description: From the shadows, the newsroom beckons, ready to come alive again.
content: I first met Kathy Ryan a few years ago when I needed a new picture of myself for The Times. We met on an autumn afternoon in the New York office that’s been headquarters since 2007.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Farnaz Fassihi
title: A heavily fortified C.I.A. base in Kabul is destroyed.
description: With an explosion heard across Kabul, Americans destroyed the base so its contents would not fall to the Taliban.
content: A controlled detonation by American forces that was heard throughout Kabul has destroyed Eagle Base, the final C.I.A. outpost outside the Kabul airport, U.S. officials said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Afghanistan Collapse and Strikes in Somalia Raise Snags for Drone Warfare Rules
description: But the Biden administration is close to finishing a new playbook for counterterrorism strikes outside conventional war zones.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration has nearly completed a policy to govern counterterrorism drone strikes and commando raids outside conventional war zones, but the abrupt collapse of the Afghan government and a recent flurry of strikes in Somalia have raised new problems, according to current and former officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: The D’Amelios Are Coming for All of Your Screens
description: TikTok’s most famous family wants to reintroduce itself on TV. Whatever that means now.
content: Peak screen was achieved this spring, beaming into a business meeting with Charli and Dixie D’Amelio, social media’s starriest sisters, and their parents, Marc and Heidi.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Family That Worked With U.S. Buries a Father and Their Hopes
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 28, 2021.
content: “The earth and sky trembled, and I fell down. All of our dreams turned to dust.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: The Giants Have a Handshake for Every Homer
description: In a magical season, San Francisco is leading the majors in wins and round-trippers. Third base coach Ron Wotus has had to get creative to give the players customized greetings.
content: The San Francisco Giants are the best team in baseball. Not widely considered a preseason favorite to contend for the playoffs, they were the first team to get to 80 wins this season and, through Friday, they were on pace to win 105 games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Paoletta
title: Give the People What They Clearly Need: More National Parks
description: There are dozens of natural wonders around the country worthy of the designation.
content: Nothing epitomizes the natural splendor of America quite like a national park. The designation evokes images of quiet groves of towering sequoias deep in the Sierra Nevadas, sweeping views of sun-drenched rock formations in the Southwest or waves crashing against granite cliffs in coastal Maine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsea Brasted
title: ‘Time is not on our side,’ New Orleans mayor warns.
description: With Hurricane Ida headed toward southeast Louisiana, Mayor LaToya Cantrell of New Orleans issued a stern warning that city residents who intend to leave should do so immediately.
content: NEW ORLEANS — With tracking maps for Hurricane Ida consistently showing an expected pathway toward southeast Louisiana, Mayor LaToya Cantrell of New Orleans issued a stern warning on Saturday that city residents who intend to leave should do so immediately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaëlle Fournier
title: A Doctor’s Tour de France, One ‘Medical Desert’ at a Time
description: Newly graduated from medical school, Martial Jardel set off on a five-month road trip to help out in areas of France suffering from a shortage of physicians.
content: LES PIEUX, France — On a sunny but chilly June morning, Dr. Martial Jardel took his black motorcycle out of his camper van, put his helmet on and started the engine. For his last day on Normandy’s Cotentin Peninsula, he was ready to hit the road along the English Channel to visit a patient.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Repression Without Borders
description: Authoritarian leaders have taken their repressive tactics global.
content: Smiting foes wherever they may be has a firm place in mythology, literature and history. The meddling Greek gods. James Bond’s license to kill. Joseph Stalin’s hit man who finally caught up with Leon Trotsky in Mexico City. Given this legacy, it is fair to ask why human rights organizations are now raising an alarm about authoritarian leaders who hunt down dissidents far from their borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Kitamura
title: Well Educated, Well Employed, and a Paycheck Away From Disaster
description: Jo Hamya’s debut novel, “Three Rooms,” exposes the precarious state of life for a woman of color in publishing.
content: THREE ROOMS By Jo Hamya
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: After Video of Abusive Nurse, Canada’s Indigenous Seek Health Overhaul
description: The abuse last year of an Indigenous woman in a Quebec hospital has prompted outrage and underlined the discrimination facing Canada’s Indigenous community.
content: MANAWAN, Quebec — As Joyce Echaquan, a 37-year-old Indigenous mother of seven, moaned in pain at a hospital in Quebec, in the final hours of her life, the torrent of insults began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Smarty Party
description: The old tradition of the ‘salon’ — where guests become members of a small, privileged audience — gains momentum.
content: On a Thursday night in August, in an empty storefront in SoHo, a group of guests in well-considered outfits gathered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Experience, Education, Vaccination: The New Qualifications for Job Seekers
description: Companies are devising vaccination policies for new hires along with rules for their existing employees.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offer a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: The Census Said Detroit Kept Shrinking. The Mayor Begs to Differ.
description: Mayor Mike Duggan, who ran on a promise to reverse generations of population decline, blamed the Census Bureau, not himself, after the head count fell again.
content: DETROIT — Once again, the Census Bureau reported, Detroit has gotten smaller.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Bowler
title: One Thing I Don’t Plan to Do Before I Die Is Make a Bucket List
description: Until my cancer diagnosis, I did not understand that one future comes at the exclusion of all others.
content: I wish someone had told me that the end of a life is a mathematical equation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Uh? Oh …
description: Dory Mintz’s puzzle has us hemming and hawing.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This theme suited the state of my August-in-New York brain perfectly and I solved the whole puzzle at a leisurely pace with a lot of, erm, breaks for cold beverages and siestas. Dory Mintz is a New Yorker too, a Bronxite, and a software engineer for a digital marketing company called “Wunderkind.” Mr. Mintz is also a bowler and a self-described “passionate albeit subpar Scrabble player,” according to the print puzzle introduction (could be that he’s just modest, hm). This is his second grid for The Times (after a Wednesday with international puns), and his Sunday debut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: In Lake Charles, Ida stirs memories of Laura.
description: As Hurricane Ida headed toward the Gulf Coast, there were signs that it could rival Hurricane Laura in strength, officials said, stirring painful reminders of the devastation Laura delivered last year and the ways many residents continue to live with its consequences.
content: As Hurricane Ida headed toward the Gulf Coast, there were signs that it could rival Hurricane Laura in strength, officials said, stirring painful reminders of the devastation Laura delivered last year and the ways many residents continue to live with its consequences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: All in or All Out? Biden Saw No Middle Ground in Afghanistan.
description: President Biden’s reductionist formula has prompted a debate over whether the mayhem in Kabul was inevitable or the result of a failure to consider other options.
content: As the American military withdrawal from Afghanistan capping an ill-fated 20-year war turned uglier and deadlier in recent days, President Biden has stood by his decision but at the same time repeatedly singled out one person in particular to blame: his predecessor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: My Neighbor’s Door Camera Faces My Apartment. Is That Legal?
description: Rental tenants typically cannot install cameras — or anything else — in common hallways. But landlords can.
content: Q: I live in a six-story rental building in Washington Heights, with five apartments per floor. My neighbor across the hall installed a Ring camera that captures the entire floor. It faces my apartment directly, providing a clear view inside whenever I open the door. Aside from the fact that it’s uncomfortable knowing that all my comings and goings are being recorded, I wonder if this is legal. What can I do about it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon take us down the twisted path of a “crypticrostic.”
content: ACROSTIC — I hope everyone looks at this marvelous puzzle as a twofer from a couple of wizards, even if it took you a bit to wrap your head around the notion of cryptic clues on an acrostic. I certainly got thrown for a loop. (A crypticrostic? I only wish I’d thought of that portmanteau, but it’s been done.) This is the first time I can remember getting almost a whole set of such off-kilter clues from Team Cox/Rathvon, and it’s a blast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: Some Say Low Interest Rates Cause Inequality. What if It’s the Reverse?
description: With an increasing share of the world’s wealth in the hands of its top earners, a savings glut is pushing asset prices up and interest rates down.
content: It’s an article of faith among many in the financial world: The Federal Reserve’s low interest rate policies and other steps meant to boost the economy are driving the value of stocks and other assets to the moon, and thus are a major cause of high wealth inequality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei, Benjamin Mueller and Robert Gebeloff
title: What Went Wrong With the Pandemic in Florida
description: Even a large state that emphasized vaccinations in combating the coronavirus can be crushed by the Delta variant when no other measures are put in place.
content: MIAMI — The unexpected and unwelcome coronavirus surge now unfolding in the United States has hit hardest in states that were slow to embrace vaccines. And then there is Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Fight by Fight, Jake Paul Strikes for Credibility
description: The social media influencer wants respect for his transformation into a main draw boxer even if his skills are beside the point.
content: Jake Paul has not had a quiet moment to think.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Bob Diamond, the ‘Tunnel King’ of Brooklyn, Dies at 61
description: First he discovered a long-forgotten rail tunnel. Then he spent decades trying — in vain — to revive Brooklyn’s trolley system.
content: Bob Diamond, an engineering-school dropout who discovered a long-forgotten rail tunnel beneath Downtown Brooklyn and later spent more than 20 years trying to revive the borough’s trolley system, only to be stymied by bureaucratic wrangling and his own eccentricities, died on Aug. 21 at his home in the borough’s Kensington section. He was 61.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: What we know about the 13 U.S. service members killed in the Kabul attack.
description: They had an average age of just over 22 and came from towns across the country.
content: The Department of Defense on Saturday identified the 13 members of the U.S. military who were killed in the attack on the airport in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Thursday as they worked to evacuate people to safety. They hailed from across the country — from California to Wyoming to Tennessee — and had an average age of just over 22. Eleven were Marines, one was a Navy medic and another was a member of the Army.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Britons, Unfazed by High Covid Rates, Weigh Their ‘Price of Freedom’
description: Britain is reporting more than 30,000 new coronavirus cases a day, but the public seems to have moved on. Experts say this could be a glimpse into the future for other countries.
content: LONDON — Nearly 60,000 soccer fans packed London’s Emirates Stadium last Sunday to watch Chelsea outplay Arsenal. Andrew Lloyd Webber’s musical “Cinderella” made its glittering debut in the West End after multiple Covid-related delays. On the subway, where masks are still mandatory, half of the riders go barefaced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Al Capone’s Possessions, Now for Sale, Show Two Sides of the Gangster
description: His granddaughters said they hoped an auction of his belongings would show that Capone was more than a ruthless mob boss. He was also a family man.
content: The first items listed for sale on the auction site listing the possessions of Al Capone portray a loving family man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz and Erinn Springer
title: A Blue-Ribbon Affair
description: In Wisconsin, as in many parts of America, state and county fairs were back this summer.
content: The Northern Wisconsin State Fair, which takes place in Chippewa Falls each summer, was, like many other state fairs, canceled last year. It was the first time in its 123-year history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Chelsea Proves a Point While Collecting One at Liverpool
description: A red card put Chelsea to the test, but a draw won with control, composure and calm felt like much more.
content: LIVERPOOL, England — Romelu Lukaku’s second half was not an especially glamorous one. There was a lot of running, darting into the slivers of space on either side of Liverpool’s central defenders, hoping for a ball that rarely came. There was a substantial amount of tussling and wrestling with Joel Matip, in particular, the two scrabbling for every inch of ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: A Journey Through Kabul on the Day of the Fall
description: A Times correspondent who grew up in the Afghan capital returned before the Taliban’s victory, taking in the end of one era and the fearful start of another.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — In the hours before the Taliban walked into Kabul, and the two-decade quest to build a democratic Afghanistan tumbled into fear and uncertainty, I left my parents’ home to take a bus around the city. This was not a reporting outing. It was personal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Christensen
title: ‘It Was Like I’d Never Done It Before’: How Sally Rooney Wrote Again
description: Her first two books, “Conversations With Friends” and “Normal People,” made her more famous than she liked. For her latest, “Beautiful World, Where Are You,” she asked herself what a novel is and why she’s taking on another one.
content: “Every day I wonder why my life has turned out this way,” a millionaire novelist named Alice writes to her friend Eileen in “Beautiful World, Where Are You,” out from Farrar, Straus & Giroux on Sept. 7. “I never advertised myself as a psychologically robust person, capable of withstanding extensive public inquiries into my personality and upbringing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: U.S. Strike Kills Two ISIS-K Militants in Retaliation for Airport Attack
description: Officials said two ISIS-K militants were killed and another was wounded in a U.S. airstrike in Afghanistan’s Nangarhar province, in retaliation for a bombing at Kabul’s airport which killed scores of people, including 13 American troops. Officials declined to say whether the targets were specifically involved in the airport attack.
content: Officials said two ISIS-K militants were killed and another was wounded in a U.S. airstrike in Afghanistan’s Nangarhar province, in retaliation for a bombing at Kabul’s airport which killed scores of people, including 13 American troops. Officials declined to say whether the targets were specifically involved in the airport attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: Ida Pounds the Caribbean with Heavy Rain
description: The storm became a Category 1 hurricane on its way toward Cuba and the U.S. Gulf Coast, with sustained wind speeds reaching 80 miles per hour. It is expected to make landfall in the U.S. on Sunday.
content: The storm became a Category 1 hurricane on its way toward Cuba and the U.S. Gulf Coast, with sustained wind speeds reaching 80 miles per hour. It is expected to make landfall in the U.S. on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 28, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 28, 2021.
content: An article on Monday about Tropical Storm Henri misstated the name of a village in Rhode Island. It is Point Judith, not Port Judith.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Climate Change: What Must Be Done, Now
description: Writers argue for eating less meat, relocating to safer zones, promoting nuclear energy and passing a carbon tax.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
